publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Šorčuqduring T III Š 79.29

seg.seg: After (King Candramukha) had been gazing (lo)ng [at Araṇemi] he speaks to him: “Surely you are a Kṣatriya: Such features show (themselves on you) ...
is the (establish)ment (of all virtues (?)). Doubting, king Candramukha speaks: “Indeed, you (are a Kṣatriya (?)) of the lord, of the king Araṇemi.” ... (Araṇemi) [however]
says nothing. Again king Candramukha speaks: “Indeed, speak! [It] (is) you after all?” (Thereupon king Araṇemi after pondering for a long time)
speaks to himself: “How shall this become now? It is not my principle to tell a lie.” (Thereupon he speaks to king Candramukha: “O great king, I am the king)
How shall it be now? It is not my way to tell lies! (cf 246; 325)
Araṇemi.” When he had heard this, king Candramukha fell down from [his] lion-throne, (grasped the feet of king Araṇemi and wailing speaks: “O divine lord,)
what has befallen you?” Thereupon he speaks: || In [the tune] devadatte || “To you, to whom mankind [was] devoted (in) any way ...
... einer, (dessen) Wunsch [es ist], dich zugrunde zu richten, oder dessen Wunsch [es ist], die höllischen Leiden zu erdulden, hat dich in [diese] Not gebracht.
... one whose wish [it is] to ruin you, or whose wish [it is] to undergo hellish sufferings, has brought you into [this] misery.
one (whose) wish [it is] to ruin you, or whose wish [it is] to make [you] see the torments of hell, has brought you in this misery. Who indeed was this ignor(ant man)? ... [1.]
Who was this foolish person?
Do tell me indeed, o lord, the reason for this matter! What other one has taken hold of your land? An (army) of ten my(riads is at my disposal ...)
Wer anders hat dein Land in Besitz genommen?
Who else has taken possession of your land?
the (lif)e lived by me. When I see the enemy of the lord face to face I will release [my] passion ... [2.] (A rain of ... I will)
If I see the enemy of the lord manifestly, I will release the passion … (cf 325)

let rain over the earth [and] with a flood of missiles I will fill all directions of the world. With dead [people] ... (the surface [of the earth?] will be filled?, step by step. In this I will take part.)
I will let rain a rain of weapons on the earth, and with a flood of weapons I will fill the cardinal directions. (cf 246; 325)
With [the bodies of the] dead the surface of the earth will be (covered?) bit by bit. I will take part in this (cf 246; 325)
Like Indra, the lord [is] looking lovely; but as a miserable one he came into my country, as such a one I leave [it] now, full of (suffering).” [3.] ...
[Araṇemi:] "(After all,) in this world there is no such hate that by [its] strength would be able (to bring) me (into) this anger.”
There is no one in this world who could have brought me into this misfortune by [his] power.

p.note: The text shows some inaccurate or colloquial spellings:
nraiṣana in shows degemination of ṣṣ, while the preterite participle srukoṣṣäṃts in has a wrong geminate.
One interesting feature is the palatal 〈ly〉 in śaul in front of following palatal ñi in .
tārko for tārkau in seems to show monophthongization.

The restorations are based on the parallel texts, the translation is based on 323-6. According to Sieg/Siegling in , the metric passage has a meter of 20|22|10|15 syllables with the rhythm a=5/5/5/5, b=8/7/7, c=5/5, and d=8/7.
Note that the parallel a 1 differs slightly by having tane instead of nano at the beginning of the sentence and, more interestingly, the imperative pokse "tell me!" instead of poñ "speak!".

taka-c for takā-c; śaśayu for śaśāyu in ; sasweṃtse for säsweṃtse in , likewise sasweṃ for säsweṃ in . While these forms are most likely mere misspellings, the next ones show some signs of colloquial TB (although one may speculate about a shift of accent in the two forms of saswe, which has an irregular paradigm in standard TB):
For the correct restoration see now the parallel text a 5.
Note that the parallel b 1 has kwri yneśne instead of krui yneśo, which is a more archaic version.

list.item:
The text shows some inaccurate or colloquial spellings:

a6. taka-c for takā-c; śaśayu for śaśāyu in b3; sasweṃtse for säsweṃtse in b3, likewise sasweṃ for säsweṃ in b6. While these forms are most likely mere misspellings, the next ones show some signs of colloquial TB (although one may speculate about a shift of accent in the two forms of saswe, which has an irregular paradigm in standard TB):

nraiṣana in b1 shows degemination of ṣṣ, while the preterite participle srukoṣṣäṃts in b4 has a wrong geminate.

One interesting feature is the palatal 〈ly〉 in śaul in front of following palatal ñi in b3.

tārko for tārkau in b3 seems to show monophthongization.

a3. Note that the parallel [[PK NS 36 and 20]] a 1 differs slightly by having tane instead of nano at the beginning of the sentence and, more interestingly, the imperative pokse "tell me!" instead of poñ "speak!".

b3. Note that the parallel [[PK NS 36 and 20]] b 1 has kwri yneśne instead of krui yneśo, which is a more archaic version.

a1 lke pilko śeśśamorm[e]ṃ weṣṣann(·)śca nemcek twe [k]_uṣattarye nes_tä\ taisa ksa ṣotruna lk[ā] /// a2 ñña ne_s_aṃ || śle sklo_k\ candramukhe walo we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ auspa _s_asweṃntse araṇemiñ lānte twe /// a3 mā we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ kca || nano candramukhe walo we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ auspa poñä\ mapi twe /// a4 ñ añ_m_ampa k[a] we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ _m_akte ñake tākaṃ mā ñi pele ste waike weṃtsi /// a5 nesau || te keklyauṣormeṃ candramukhe walo ṣecakecce asāṃmeṃ ñor klāya ara /// a6 k_use te taka-cä\ || tumeṃ we_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ || devadattenne || ket śāmñe śaiṣṣe aiwau po-ykne /// b1 tsi āñme nraiṣana to _l_aklenta su ci klāte ñyātsene : k_use nai [ṅ]k(e) [p](·) su aknā /// b2 pokse-ñ nai saswa ṣar_m\ cwi wäntrentse k_use ksa allek tañä\ eṅsate yapoyä\ śak ko /// b3 ly ñi śaśayu : sanaṃ sasweṃtse lakau kr_ui yneśo : tārko eṅ_k_a_l\ /// b4 _s_askau keṃtsa tsainwāṣṣai l(·)ñsa _k_alymiṃ prutkaskau : sruko_ṣ_ṣ_aṃts a /// b5 ylai-ñäkte ram no lare-yok sasweṃ : tallāw ram no śem ñi ypoyne se ñke_k\ lnaskau śle /// b6 śconiye mā su ksa ne_s_aṃ ce śaiṣṣene k_use ñiś maiyyasa cämpalle ṣai ceṃ erkatñe ///

The restorations are based on the parallel texts, the translation is based on [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 323-6. According to Sieg/Siegling in [[TochSprR(B) II]], the metric passage has a meter of 20|22|10|15 syllables with the rhythm a=5/5/5/5, b=8/7/7, c=5/5, and d=8/7.

b2. For the correct restoration see now the parallel text [[PK NS 36 and 20]] a 5.

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a4 How shall it be now? It is not my way to tell lies! (cf [[Couvreur 1964]]: 246; [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 325) 302
b1 Who was this foolish person? 353
b3 If I see the enemy of the lord manifestly, I will release the passion … (cf [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 325) 670
b4 I will let rain a rain of weapons on the earth, and with a flood of weapons I will fill the cardinal directions. (cf [[Couvreur 1964]]: 246; [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 325) 670
b4 With [the bodies of the] dead the surface of the earth will be (covered?) bit by bit. I will take part in this (cf [[Couvreur 1964]]: 246; [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 325) 670
b6 There is no one in this world who could have brought me into this misfortune by [his] power. 340


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a6-b1 ... einer, (dessen) Wunsch [es ist], dich zugrunde zu richten, oder dessen Wunsch [es ist], die höllischen Leiden zu erdulden, hat dich in [diese] Not gebracht. 393
b2 Wer anders hat dein Land in Besitz genommen? 396


a6 taka-c for tāka-c: the prt. is takā-c (MP) Done! (MM) p(i) b1 is probably simply ṣai as in the Paris parallel. This needs to be noted. Michael (Thu, 2016-05-19, 10:41:31 (CEST))

|(wa-) a1 walke|lke pilko śeśśamormeṃ weṣṣäṃ-neśc|weṣṣann(e)śca nemcek twe kṣatriye|k_uṣattarye nest taisa ksa ṣotruna lkāntär-c_(Prs.)|lkā(ntär-c) /// ścmoñña|(ścmo)|ñña a2 nesäṃ_(Sg.)|nesäṃ || śle sklok candramukhe walo weṣṣäṃ auspa säswentse|säsweṃntse araṇemiñ lānte twe /// a3 mā weṣṣäṃ kca || nano candramukhe walo weṣṣäṃ auspa poñ mapi twe (nest tane araṇemi walo walke pälskontasa ṣañ|ṣa)|ñ a4 añmämpa ka weṣṣäṃ mäkte ñake tākaṃ_(Sg.)|tākaṃ mā ñi pele ste waike wentsi|weṃtsi (tumeṃ candramukheṃ lāntäśc weṣṣäṃ oroccu walo se ñiś araṇemi – walo) a5 nesau || te keklyauṣormeṃ candramukhe walo ṣecakecce asāṃmeṃ ñor klāya ara(ṇemiñ lānte paine yäksau pälwāmane weṣṣäṃ ñäkte-yok saswa) a6 k_use te takā-c|taka-c || tumeṃ weṣṣäṃ || devadattene|devadattenne || # ket śāmñe śaiṣṣe ; aiwau po-ykne(sa ;) /// (– – – – – –) %7 naktsi|(naktsy āñme #1a kete wat no) , lkātsi|(lkā)|tsi b1 āñme ; nraiṣṣana|nraiṣana to«ṃ» , läklenta ; su ci klāte , ñyātsene : #1b k_use nai ṅk(e) p(i) su ; aknā(tsa śaumo) #1c /// %15 #1d b2 pokse-ñ nai saswa ; ṣarm cwi wäntarentse|wäntrentse ; k_use ksa allek tañ ; eṅksate|eṅsate yapoy #2a śak ko(ṭanma , retke ñi ste ;) /// %9 śaul|(śau)|ly b3 ñi , śaśāyu|śaśayu : #2b sanaṃ säswentse|sasweṃtse ; lakau kwri|kr_ui yneś|yneśo : #2c tārkau|tārko eṅkäl , /// %11 #2d (swese – – –) ; swāsäskau_(Sub.)|(swā)|säskau b4 kentsa|keṃtsa ; tsainwāṣṣai l(ā)ñsa ; kälymiṃ prutkaskau_(Sub.)|prutkaskau : #3a srukoṣäṃts|srukoṣṣäṃts a- /// , %6 (ānte , ike-postäṃ|yke-postäṃ ; yāmmar pāke , tentse ñiś :) #3b b5 ylai-ñäkte ramt|ram no ; lare-yok säsweṃ|sasweṃ : #3c tallāw ramt|ram no , śem ñi ypoyne ; se ñkek lnaskau , śle (lakle) #3d /// (akañc) b6 śconiye mā su ksa nesäṃ_(Sg.)|nesäṃ ce śaiṣṣene k_use ñiś maiyyasa cämpalle ṣai ceṃ erkattäññene|erkatñe(ne kalatsi) ///

a1 After (King Candramukha) had been gazing (lo)ng [at Araṇemi] he speaks to him: “Surely you are a Kṣatriya: Such features show (themselves on you) ... a2 is the (establish)ment (of all virtues (?)). Doubting, king Candramukha speaks: “Indeed, you (are a Kṣatriya (?)) of the lord, of the king Araṇemi.” ... (Araṇemi) [however] a3 says nothing. Again king Candramukha speaks: “Indeed, speak! [It] (is) you after all?” (Thereupon king Araṇemi after pondering for a long time) a4 speaks to himself: “How shall this become now? It is not my principle to tell a lie.” (Thereupon he speaks to king Candramukha: “O great king, I am the king) a5 Araṇemi.” When he had heard this, king Candramukha fell down from [his] lion-throne, (grasped the feet of king Araṇemi and wailing speaks: “O divine lord,) a6 what has befallen you?” Thereupon he speaks: || In [the tune] devadatte || “To you, to whom mankind [was] devoted (in) any way ... b1 one (whose) wish [it is] to ruin you, or whose wish [it is] to make [you] see the torments of hell, has brought you in this misery. Who indeed was this ignor(ant man)? ... [1.] b2 Do tell me indeed, o lord, the reason for this matter! What other one has taken hold of your land? An (army) of ten my(riads is at my disposal ...) b3 the (lif)e lived by me. When I see the enemy of the lord face to face I will release [my] passion ... [2.] (A rain of ... I will) b4 let rain over the earth [and] with a flood of missiles I will fill all directions of the world. With dead [people] ... (the surface [of the earth?] will be filled?, step by step. In this I will take part.) b5 Like Indra, the lord [is] looking lovely; but as a miserable one he came into my country, as such a one I leave [it] now, full of (suffering).” [3.] ... b6 [Araṇemi:] "(After all,) in this world there is no such hate that by [its] strength would be able (to bring) me (into) this anger.”

div.p: taka-c for tāka-c: the prt. is takā-c (MP) Done! (MM) p(i) b1 is probably simply ṣai as in the Paris parallel. This needs to be noted. Michael (Thu, 2016-05-19, 10:41:31 (CEST))
